user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_mkdir:
```c
int32 OS_mkdir(const char *path, uint32 access)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_DirCreate_Impl(local_path, access);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_mkdir:
int32 OS_TranslatePath(const char *VirtualPath, char *LocalPath)
{
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    int32                         return_code;
    const char *                  name_ptr;
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    size_t                        SysMountPointLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathLen;
    size_t                        VirtPathBegin;

    /*
    ** Check to see if the path pointers are NULL
    */
    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(VirtualPath);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(LocalPath);

    /*
    ** Check length
    */
    VirtPathLen = OS_strnlen(VirtualPath, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN);
    if (VirtPathLen >= OS_MAX_PATH_LEN)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
    }

    /* checks to see if there is a '/' somewhere in the path */
    name_ptr = strrchr(VirtualPath, '/');
    if (name_ptr == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* strrchr returns a pointer to the last '/' char, so we advance one char */
    name_ptr = name_ptr + 1;
    if (memchr(name_ptr, 0, OS_MAX_FILE_NAME) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    SysMountPointLen = 0;
    VirtPathBegin    = VirtPathLen;

    /*
    ** All valid Virtual paths must start with a '/' character
    */
    if (VirtualPath[0] != '/')
    {
        return OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }

    /* Get a reference lock, as a filesystem check could take some time. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)VirtualPath, &token);

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
    }
    else
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM) != 0)
        {
            SysMountPointLen = OS_strnlen(filesys->system_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt));
            VirtPathBegin    = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));
            if (SysMountPointLen < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(LocalPath, filesys->system_mountpt, SysMountPointLen);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (VirtPathLen < VirtPathBegin)
        {
            return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;
        }
        else
        {
            VirtPathLen -= VirtPathBegin;
            if ((SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen) < OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN)
            {
                memcpy(&LocalPath[SysMountPointLen], &VirtualPath[VirtPathBegin], VirtPathLen);
                LocalPath[SysMountPointLen + VirtPathLen] = 0;
            }
            else
            {
                return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_DirCreate_Impl(const char *local_path, uint32 access)
{
    struct stat st;
    int32       return_code;

    if (mkdir(local_path, S_IFDIR | S_IRWXU | S_IRWXG | S_IRWXO) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;

        if (errno == EEXIST)
        {
            /* Success if already exists and is a directory */
            if (stat(local_path, &st) == 0 && S_ISDIR(st.st_mode))
            {
                return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments were identified in the provided code. Rationale by function:

- OS_mkdir: This function has a simple, conditional flow: it calls OS_TranslatePath and, only if that returns OS_SUCCESS, calls OS_DirCreate_Impl. Both branches (path translation success and failure) are reachable depending on inputs; there are no statements following an unconditional return that would be unreachable.

- OS_TranslatePath: The function contains multiple early returns to signal various error conditions (NULL pointers via macros, path too long, missing '/', name too long, invalid starting '/', object lookup failure, etc.). These early returns are legitimate guard/error exits and each can be triggered by specific inputs; none of them render subsequent code unreachable in all cases. The critical resource (token) is released only when it was successfully obtained (inside the else branch); there is no path that both uses the token and skips its release. The later processing (copying mount point and virtual path) is guarded by if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) and thus only executed when the prior steps succeeded — this is acceptable flow control, not unreachable code.

- OS_DirCreate_Impl: Both the mkdir-failure and mkdir-success branches are reachable. The code correctly checks errno for EEXIST and then checks with stat() whether the path is a directory; neither branch contains unreachable statements.

- Macros/definitions: The provided defines (OS_SUCCESS, OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN) do not introduce unreachable code in the shown functions.

Given these points, there are no code fragments that appear to be impossible to reach due to program logic, nor any obvious dead/unreachable statements introduced by unconditional returns or mutually exclusive conditions that make code permanently unreachable. Therefore no fragments are reported for investigation.
